questions.question: Which is the most popular JavaScript framework?
Which company invented React?
What's the fundamental building block of React apps?
What's the name of the syntax we use to describe the UI in React components?
How does data flow naturally in React apps?
How to pass data into a child component?
When to use derived state?
options: Whenever the state should not trigger a re-render
Whenever the state can be synchronized with an effect
Whenever the state should be accessible to all components
Whenever the state can be computed from another state variable

questions.question: What triggers a UI re-render in React?
options: Adding event listeners to DOM elements

questions.question: When do we directly "touch" the DOM in React?
options: When we need to listen to an event
When we need to change the UI
When we need to add styles

questions.question: In what situation do we use a callback to update state?
options: When updating the state will be slow
When the updated state is very data-intensive
When the state update should happen faster
When the new state depends on the previous state

questions.question: If we pass a function to useState, when will that function be called?
options: Each time we update the state
The first time we update the state

questions.question: Which hook to use for an API request on the component's initial render?
Which variables should go into the useEffect dependency array?
options: All state and props referenced in the effect
All variables needed for clean up

questions.question: An effect will always run on the initial render.
options: It depends on the dependency array
In depends on the code in the effect

questions.question: When will an effect run if it doesn't have a dependency array?
options: The first time the component re-renders
Each time the component is re-rendered

questions.question: What is the type of `null` in JavaScript?
Which keyword is used to declare a constant in JavaScript?
How can you convert a string to an integer in JavaScript?
Which method can be used to join two arrays in JavaScript?
What does the `map()` method return?
options: A new array with transformed elements
The first element that matches a condition

questions.question: What is a 'closure' in JavaScript?
options: A function having access to its own scope, parent scope, and global scope
A function with no return value
A variable that holds a function

questions.question: Which of the following is true about 'let' and 'var'?
What will the following code log: `console.log(1 + '2' + 3)`?
Which JavaScript function is used to schedule a task to run after a delay?
Which statement correctly explains the 'this' keyword in JavaScript?
options: 'this' refers to the global object in non-strict mode
'this' refers to the previous object in the scope chain
'this' refers to the return value of the function

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'use strict' directive?
options: Enforces strict syntax rules in JavaScript
Enables strict mode for variable typing
Allows better optimization by the JavaScript engine

questions.question: What is an Immediately Invoked Function Expression (IIFE) in JavaScript?
options: A function that is immediately called after its definition
A function that is invoked on an event
A function that cannot return a value
A function that is always recursive

questions.question: What will the following code log: `console.log(typeof NaN)`?
How can you deep clone an object in JavaScript?
What does `Promise.resolve()` do?
options: Returns the result of a promise
Waits for all promises to resolve

options: To initialize an object when it is created
To destroy an object when it goes out of scope

questions.question: Which keyword is used to define an abstract class in C++?
What happens when you delete a pointer twice in C++?
options: It results in a segmentation fault
The program compiles and runs without issues

questions.question: What is the use of the 'virtual' keyword in C++?
options: To declare a function that can be overridden in a derived class
To declare a function without a return type
To prevent a function from being overridden
To declare a function as inline

questions.question: Which operator cannot be overloaded in C++?
What does the 'new' keyword do in C++?
options: It allocates memory on the heap for a new object
It reallocates memory for an object
It creates a copy of an object
It initializes a new object on the stack

questions.question: Which of the following is true about references in C++?
options: A reference can be reseated to another object
A reference must be initialized when declared
References are equivalent to pointers in all aspects
References cannot be used as function parameters

questions.question: What is a 'pure virtual function' in C++?
options: A function with no return type
A function declared using the 'abstract' keyword
A function defined only in derived classes

questions.question: What is the time complexity of accessing an element in a C++ vector (on average)?
Which of the following best describes a C++ destructor?
options: A function that cleans up memory when an object is destroyed
A function that creates a copy of an object
A function that initializes an object
A function that deletes an object from memory

options: To refer to the instance of the class
To refer to the class itself

questions.question: Which keyword is used to create a generator in Python?
What happens when you try to modify a tuple in Python?
options: The tuple is automatically converted to a list

questions.question: What is the use of the 'with' keyword in Python?
options: To simplify exception handling by encapsulating cleanup tasks

questions.question: Which operator is used for floor division in Python?
What does the 'lambda' keyword do in Python?

options: Lists can contain elements of different types
Lists are the same as tuples

questions.question: What is a 'decorator' in Python?
options: A function that modifies another function
A keyword that defines a function
A function that returns multiple values

options: A function that cleans up memory
